Award.AwardTitle: Whillans Ice Stream Subglacial Access Research Drilling: Integrative Study of Marine Ice Sheet Stability and Subglacial Habitats in West Antarctica
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Title: Whillans Ice Stream Subglacial Access Research Drilling: Integrative Study of Marine Ice Sheet Stability and Subglacial Habitats in West Antarctica
Institution: Montana State University
Abstract Date: 06/25/2014

The WISSARD (Whillans Ice Stream Subglacial Access and Research Drilling) Project has been awarded a two-part, multi-year grant (September 2009-August 2015). The aim of the project is to drill beneath the 1000 meter thick West Antarctic ice sheet, allowing investigation of glaciological, geological, microbiological, geochemical, and oceanographic systems, with a focus on the role of subglacial liquid water including subglacial lakes. A 2007 National Research Council (NRC) report stated "It is time for scientific research on subglacial lakes to begin". The WISSARD project is the United States contribution to subglacial lake research. The current award is a renewal of the earlier project, and will allow completion of one component of the work (the grounding line studies).

The overall WISSARD project continues to study the overarching hypothesis that active water drainage connects various subglacial environments and exerts major control on ice sheet flow, geochemistry, metabolic and phylogenetic diversity, and biogeochemical transformations. Global warming, melting of ice sheets, and subsequent sea-level rise are of high societal relevance, and the WISSARD project contributes significantly to our understanding of carbon cycling and ice sheet dynamics. The technological infrastructure built as part of the project will benefit the broader science community for years to come. The project has increased student
participation in polar research, introduced new investigators to the polar sciences,
enriched K-12 teaching and learning programs, and reached a larger public audience through such venues as popular science magazines, museum based activities and videography and documentary films. In summary, WISSARD promotes scientific exploration of Antarctica by conveying to the public the excitement of accessing and studying what may be some of the last unexplored aquatic environments on Earth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Past studies in West Antarctica have highlighted the importance of ice sheet interactions with water, either at the basal boundary where ice streams are in contact with active subglacial hydrologic systems, or at the Grounding Zone (GZ) where the ice sheet meets the ocean. Water and wet sediments can control the rate of ice stream flow and trigger changes in flow rates over short timescales. Recent biological investigations have also shown that subglacial environments are habitable. Just as streaming ice flow is dependent on availability and dynamics of bulk subglacial water and wet sediments, subglacial microbial ecosystems rely on these physical settings to supply water, nutrients, and energy sources.

 

The WISSARD project used an “integrated systems” approach to one region of the ice sheet that contains an intersection of the subglacial environment, the sub-ice shelf cavity and the grounding zone itself, the northern section of Whillans Ice Stream (WIS) in West Antarctica. We studied these environments using a combination of geophysical imaging, GPS surveying, satellite data, in-situ measurements and laboratory experiments to test the overarching hypothesis: “The dynamic glaciology, sedimentological, and biochemical processes combine to stabilize the ice shelf and control the structure and function of microorganisms inhabiting the region.” 

 

GPS data revealed cascading subglacial floods and resulting ice-velocity changes. These connected subglacial hydrology events caused two years of enhanced ice flow, with three episodic velocity fluctuations of up to nearly 4% correlated to lake drainage evolution. This type of short-term velocity fluctuation driven by internal mechanisms and has important implications for ensuring that observational techniques meant for determining long-term changes to the ice sheet are unbiased by short-lived internal variability. The study region moves via stick-slip motion, and for an eleven-month period changes in subglacial hydrology disrupted the timing of this tidally-paced stick-slip cycle, providing new insight into ice stream basal dynamics (Figs. 1-3).

We developed a process model in which channels are mechanically eroded into deformable subglacial sediment rather than melted into the overlying ice. When applied to the known lakes of the Whillans/Mercer system, the model successfully reproduced the key characteristics estimated lake volume changes between 2003 and 2009. This result implies that most active lakes are shallow and only exist in the presence of saturated sediment, explaining why they are difficult to detect with classical radar methods. It also implies that the lake-drainage process is sensitive to the composition and strength of the till, suggesting that models could be improved with a realistic treatment of sediment – interfacial water exchange.

Direct access to the subglacial cavity via hot-water drilling allowed the composition of microorganisms in water samples and from a 12 cm sediment core to be determined.  Molecular analysis of nucleic acid sequences revealed that the diverse bacterial and archaeal communities inhabiting the water column and underlying sediments were compositionally distinct from those in the drilling and borehole water. Many of the microorganisms inferred to be abundant in the Whillans Ice Stream (WIS)-GZ community were most closely related to species found in deep sea habitats including cold seeps and basalts. The prevalence of taxa phylogenetically related to microbial species that derive energy from the oxidation of reduced sulfur or nitrogen compounds (chemolithoautotrophs) implies an important role for sulfide and ammonia oxidation in these ecosystems (Fig. 4).

We compared the microbial community structure of the WIS-GZ to that of Subglacial Lake Whillans (SLW) and the marine waters collected near the calving front of the McMurdo Ice Shelf (MIS; Figure 2A) and found the WIS-GZ communities to be statistically distinct from the other sites. Although communities at the WIS-GZ most closely resembled the MIS site (Fig. 5), a large portion of the WIS-GZ sediment sequence reads were shared with those of the SLW sediment communities. The similarities between the WIS-GZ and SLW communities may be linked to subglacial drainage or historical connection of SLW to the marine system.

Flux models revealed that subglacial exports of carbon and nutrients from the Siple Coast fertilize the ocean waters beneath the Ross Ice Shelf (RIS). These models showed that microbial activity is the source of organic matter in SLW, and that regional hydrological connectivity can explain the biogeochemical conditions observed in the lake. Fluxes of organic matter and inorganic nutrients from subglacial environments along the Siple Coast indicated that these inputs were sufficient to support marine food web productivity under the RIS (Table 1, Fig. 6).

Observations made by the Deep SCINI ROV clearly showed the basal ice to marine water transition, numerous types of fish (Fig. 7), and several types of amphipods. ROV cameras also provided the first images of basal ice sediment and its role in forming a drape over the benthic sediments.
